head.title: Bipolymer-Cross-Linked Binder to Improve the Reversibility and Kinetics of Sodiation and Desodiation of Antimony for Sodium-Ion Batteries | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Bipolymer-Cross-Linked Binder to Improve the Reversibility and Kinetics of Sodiation and Desodiation of Antimony for Sodium-Ion Batteries

Although the volume of antimony tremendously expands during the alloying reaction with sodium, it is considered a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Repeated volume changes along the sodiation/desodiation cycles encourage capacity fading by triggering pulverization accompanying electrolyte decomposition. Additionally, the low cation transference number of sodium ions is another hindrance for application in SIBs. In this work, a binder was designed for the antimony in SIB cells to ensure bifunctionality and improve (1) the mechanical toughness to suppress the serious volume change and (2) the transference number of sodium ions. A cross-linked composite of poly(acrylic acid) and cyanoethyl pullulan (pullulan-CN) was presented as the binder. The polysaccharide backbone of pullulan-CN was responsible for the mechanical toughness, while the cyanoethyl groups of pullulan-CN improved the lithium-cation transfer. The antimony-based SIB cells using the composite binder showed improved cycle life with enhanced kinetics. The capacity was maintained at 76% of the initial value at the 200th cycle of 1C discharge following 1C charge, while the capacity at 20C was 61% of the capacity at 0.2C, implying that the composite binder significantly improved the sodiation/desodiation reversibility of antimony.

div.p:
Although the volume of antimony tremendously expands during the alloying reaction with sodium, it is considered a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Repeated volume changes along the sodiation/desodiation cycles encourage capacity fading by triggering pulverization accompanying electrolyte decomposition. Additionally, the low cation transference number of sodium ions is another hindrance for application in SIBs. In this work, a binder was designed for the antimony in SIB cells to ensure bifunctionality and improve (1) the mechanical toughness to suppress the serious volume change and (2) the transference number of sodium ions. A cross-linked composite of poly(acrylic acid) and cyanoethyl pullulan (pullulan-CN) was presented as the binder. The polysaccharide backbone of pullulan-CN was responsible for the mechanical toughness, while the cyanoethyl groups of pullulan-CN improved the lithium-cation transfer. The antimony-based SIB cells using the composite binder showed improved cycle life with enhanced kinetics. The capacity was maintained at 76% of the initial value at the 200
th
cycle of 1C discharge following 1C charge, while the capacity at 20C was 61% of the capacity at 0.2C, implying that the composite binder significantly improved the sodiation/desodiation reversibility of antimony.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Alloying reactions between the elements of Groups 14 and 15 of the periodic table (Si, Ge, Sn, and Sb) and the alkali metals in Group 1 (Li and Na) have been used in the cathodic processes of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) during charge, respectively.
(1â3)
High capacities can be achieved by the alloying reactions, such as 4200 mAh g
Si
â1
for Li
4.4
Si vs 954 mAh g
Si
â1
for NaSi and 660 mAh g
Sb
â1
for Li
3
Sb and Na
3
Sb.
(4â7)
However, a significantly large amount of alkali metal is incorporated into the metals and metalloids. Thus, severe volume expansion is inevitable (e.g., 393% volume expansion from Sb to Na
3
Sb).
(8,9)
The repeated volume change along the lithiation/delithiation cycles encourages particle pulverization, isolation of particles from electric pathways, breaking electrode integrity, and triggering electrolyte decomposition on the fresh surface of pulverized anode materials.
(10)
This pulverization issue has been addressed by controlling the characteristic dimension of the anode materials (e.g., introducing porosity or adapting nanodimensional particles),
(11,12)
coating the active materials with conductive materials,
(13â17)
and hybridizing the active materials with nonactive materials.
(18â21)

It has been reported that the volume change in the alloying reaction-based anode materials and its following effects were suppressed by adopting binders with mechanical toughness (e.g., alginate, carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), amylopectin, and pullulan)
(22â24)
and covalent and hydrogen bond formation between the surface oxides of active materials and functional groups of polymers (e.g., poly(acrylic acid) (PAA), guar gum, and a copolymer containing Meldrumâs acid).
(25â27)
Both mechanical toughness and bond formation were achieved by combining the bond-forming PAA with mechanically tough polymers (e.g., pectin, CMC, and pullulan).
(28,29)
These bifunctional bipolymer binder systems provided a more improved reversibility in electrochemical silicon-alloying reaction.
(30,31)

The majority of binder works for alloying-reaction-based anode materials have been devoted to lithiation alloying reactions, while the number of works for sodiation is limited.
(32,33)
The transport properties of sodium ions should be considered when binders for SIB anodes are developed. The abundance of sodium on Earth has triggered the development of SIBs as an alternative to LIBs;
(34,35)
however, the size of sodium ions, which is larger than that of lithium ions (1.03 Ã for Na
+
vs 0.73 Ã for Li
+
), limits their mass-transfer and charge-transfer kinetics.
(36,37)
In addition to suppressing pulverization, it is useful in installing an active transport mechanism of sodium ions into active materials through binders surrounding the active materials. In our previous work, we demonstrated that cyanoethyl poly(vinyl alcohol) cross-linked with PAA played a role of increasing the transport number of lithium ions (
t
Li
+
).
(38,39)

In this work, we present a novel binder system composed of cyanoethyl pullulan (pullulan-CN) cross-linked with PAA for antimony-based SIBs (
Figure
1
). The polysaccharide backbone of pullulan-CN provides mechanical toughness to suppress the volume expansion of antimony during sodiation, while the cyanoethyl groups of pullulan-CN facilitate the transport of sodium ions (high sodium ion transport number
t
Na
+
). The dissolution of pullulan-CN in the electrolyte was prevented by cross-linking pullulan-CN with PAA. The bipolymer composite binder system (PAA/pullulan-CN) was compared with PAA and PAA/pullulan to decouple the effects of the mechanical toughness factor and transference number factor on cell performances. As a result, PAA/pullulan-CN drove antimony-based SIBs to work the most reversibly along the sodiation/desodiation cycles.

div.p: Figure 1. Chemical structures of PAA and pullulan-CN and their cross-linking dehydration reaction to form PAA/pullulan-CN.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Submicrometer-particular antimony (â¼200 nm) was prepared by reducing Sb
3+
(
Figure S1
). A total of 0.6 g of NaBH
4
was introduced into 1 g of SbCl
3
in 50 mL of ethanol. The solution was stirred at 150 rpm for 3 h at room temperature. The Sb particles were recovered and washed through vacuum filtration using excess ethanol and deionized water. The Sb particles were dried under vacuum at 120 Â°C and then freeze-dried at â120 Â°C (Operon FDCF-12012). Two different bipolymeric composite binder solutions were prepared. Pullulan (MW = 200â¯000; Sigma-Aldrich) or pullulan-CN (MW = 316â¯000; Shin-Etsu Chemical) was mixed with PAA (MW = 250â¯000; Sigma-Aldrich) at 8:2 wt ratio in
N
-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) at 80 Â°C.

The 2032-coin-type configuration was used for the antimony-based SIB half cells, with sodium metal for counterelectrode that had a glass fiber membrane (Wattman) as the separator. The slurry of antimony particles, binder polymer, and carbon black at 7:1.5:1.5 wt ratio in NMP was loaded on copper foil at 1.4 mg cm
â2
(1.0 mg Sb cm
â2
). Then, the antimony electrodes were dried at 150 Â°C for 3 h in vacuum. One molar NaClO
4
in EC/PC (1:1 v/v) with 10 wt % fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) additives was used as the electrolyte (EC = ethylene carbonate, PC = propylene carbonate, FEC = fluoroethylene carbonate). The assembled cells were aged 45 Â°C for 3 h before electrochemical characterization. The SIB cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox (MOTEK).

The antimony-based SIB cells were galvanostatically charged/discharged between 0.01 and 2.0 V (WonATech WBCS3000). The first cycle was operated at 0.05C (33 mA g
â1
) to form the stable solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained by scanning the potential at various scan rates (Biologic). The transference number of sodium ions (
t
Na
+
) was measured using the potentiostatic polarization method (VSP-300, BioLogic). Sodium metal symmetric cells were constructed using the glass fiber separator (Wattman) used in the SIB cells between the metals. The separator was coated with a tested binder (PAA, PAA/pullulan, or PAA/pullulan-CN) by soaking the separator in the corresponding 10 wt % binder solution and then drying at 150 Â°C for 3 h. The electrolyte used in SIB cells was injected into the sodium symmetric cells.

At least four cells having the same composition were tested at the same conditions to confirm the reproducibility of electrochemical data of galvanostatic charge/discharge and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Additional cells were tested if four sets of data from the four different cells did not guarantee reproducibility.

Functional groups of the binders were spectroscopically characterized using infrared (Bruker Î±). The adhesion strength of 10 Î¼m-thick antimony composite electrodes was measured by 180Â° adhesive peel strength test described in ASTM D1876. The tensile strength of 50 Î¼m thick binder films was measured by stretching the films using the tensile strength machine (Petrol LAB DA-01). The microstructural morphology of the antimony electrodes was investigated using the scanning electron microscopy (SEM; S-4800 Cold FE-SEM). The solidâelectrolyte interphase layer of the electrodes was characterized by a X-ray photoelectron spectroscope (XPS; ESCALAB 250XI) with C 1s peak focusing.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
PAA/pullulan-CN-based antimony anodes were prepared to ensure the cross-linkage between PAA and pullulan-CN and strong bonds between PAA and antimony. Copper current collectors were coated with the anode slurry containing antimony particles with PAA/pullulan-CN. Then, the anode was aged at 150 Â°C for 3 h. PAA was strongly bound to the antimony surface as the condensation reaction between the carboxyl side chain of PAA and the hydroxyl groups of the surface oxide of antimony proceeded at the aging temperature.
(40)
Simultaneously, PAA and pullulan-CN were cross-linked via the condensation reaction between the carboxyl groups of PAA and the hydroxyl groups of pullulan-CN (
Figure
1
).
(29)
The cross-linked biopolymer binder system, PAA/pullulan-CN, was insoluble in electrolytes used for SIBs (e.g., a mixture of propylene carbonate (PC) with 1 M NaClO
4
) at least for a period longer than a week, while the Pullulan-CN remained soluble for 2 h.

The chemical structure of the PAA/pullulan-CN binder as well as the bipolymer condensation reaction was confirmed spectroscopically (using the infrared (IR) spectra in
Figure S2
and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) in
Figure S3
). In the IR spectra, the intensity of the hydroxyl peak of pullulan (â¼3304 cm
â1
) decreased after cyanoethylation (pullulan-CN), while the peak responsible for nitrile (â¼2250 cm
â1
) appeared in pullulan-CN. This supports the finding that the hydroxyl groups of pullulan were replaced by the nitrile-containing groups. There was no change in the nitrile peak after combining pullulan-CN with PAA (PAA/pullulan-CN) via condensation reaction at 150 Â°C under vacuum. Pullulan-CN, well-dissolved in the electrolyte, was not soluble in the same electrolyte after the polymer was cross-linked with PAA (
Figure S4
). The carboxylate peak at 1695 cm
â1
of PAA was shifted to the ester peaks at 1703 cm
â1
after cross-linking PAA with pullulan or pullulan-CN (PAA/pullulan or PAA/pullulan-CN). Simultaneously, the hydroxyl peaks of pullulan and pullulan-CN disappeared after the condensation reaction between the carboxyl side chain of PAA and the hydroxyl groups of the surface oxide of antimony.
(24)
In addition, two carboxylate moieties of PAA were combined to form anhydride (1801 cm
â1
).
(29)
In addition to the IR spectra, XPS analysis (
Figure S3
) is provided to confirm the cross-linkage of the binder. The disappearance of the âOH peak and the increase in the âCOâ peak in the XPS O1s spectra of PAA/pullulan-CN after cross-linking at 150 Â°C under vacuum supported the cross-linkage based on the ester (âCOOâ) bond evolution resulting from the condensation reaction between hydroxyl groups (âOH) of pullulan-CN and carboxyl groups of PAA (
Figure S3
).

The mechanical properties of binders, such as stiffness and elasticity, were investigated because they affect the events of volume expansion and pulverization significantly (
Figure
2
a
). The PAA film was easily elongated by a small stress. The elastic modulus of PAA (1.03 MPa) was too small to resist the volume expansion of antimony during sodiation. The PAA became mechanically stiffer after being cross-linked with polysaccharide (elastic modulus = 1.75 MPa for PAA/pullulan and 4.68 MPa for PAA/pullulan-CN). The cross-linkage and higher elastic moduli of pullulan and pullulan-CN are responsible for the increase in mechanical stiffness. Dipoleâdipole interaction of nitrile groups encouraged PAA/pullulan-CN to be stiffer than PAA/pullulan.
(41)
However, both pullulan-based composite binders were less stiff than PAA/CMC (6.75 MPa), which is the binder popularly used for silicon anodes. The elasticity of the pullulan backbone of pullulan-CN originates from the reversible chair-to-boat transition of the pyranose unit of the polysaccharide on elongation.
(28,42)
The Î±-glycosidic linkages of pullulan allow molecular-level conformational change, while the conformation of polysaccharide based on Î²-glycosidic linkages such as CMC is fixed at chair even after elongation. In our previous work,
(39)
a more durable operation of silicon LIB was demonstrated by using pullulan cross-linked with PAA (PAA/pullulan) instead of the popularly used PAA/CMC. The PAA/pullulan let silicon anodes breathe in and out the lithium ions with volume change, instead of fixing their dimensions.

div.p:
Figure 2. Mechanical and electrochemical properties of PAA, PAA/pullulan, PAA/pullulan-CN, and PAA/CMC. (a) Tensile stress vs strain. Fifty microns thick binder films were stretched. (b) Adhesion of electrodes on current collector. Ten microns thick active layers of antimony in the presence of a binder were peeled off from current collectors. (c) Transference number of sodium ion (Na
+
). (d) RandlesâSevcik plot:
i
pc
= cathodic peak current at 0.39 V (
Figure S5
);
v
= scan rate in V s
â1
. Electrochemically active surface areas (ECSA) were calculated from the corresponding slope by RandlesâSevcik equation. The number next to each plot is the value of relative ECSA with respect to PAA.

div.div:
The adhesion and cohesion of PAA/pullulan-CN were investigated by peeling off the Sb-containing active layers loaded on copper foil from the foil using the 3 M Magic tape (
Figure
2
b). The active layer containing PAA/pullulan-CN was the least detached, indicating the strongest adhesion. The minimum strength after the peel-off point was 0.65 N/mm for PAA/pullulan-CN, 0.41 N/mm for PAA/pullulan, 0.282 N/mm for PAA/CMC, and 0.18 N/mm for PAA. All masses of the active layers based on PAA/pullulan-CN were detached from the foil and found on the 3 M Magic tape after the peel-off. This confirmed that PAA/pullulan-CN guaranteed a strong cohesion between the electrode components (active material and carbon black) and, therefore, integrity. However, the pullulan-absent, cyanoethyl-absent, and pullulan-substitute binders (PAA, PAA/pullulan, and PAA/CMC, respectively) exhibited a lower and uneven peel strength. Only a portion of the mass of the active layer left on the 3 M Magic tape confirmed the poor cohesion strength. It was reported that the nitrile pendants of polyarylene ether nitrile enhanced its adhesion ability due to their polar interaction.
(41,43)

From the viewpoint of ionics, PAA/pullulan-CN showed the highest sodium ion transference number (
t
Na
+
;
Figure
2
c
), which was 0.68 for PAA/pullulan-CN vs 0.49 for its cyanoethyl-absent counterpart (PAA/pullulan), 0.38 for its pullulan-absent counterpart (PAA), and 0.37 for the pullulan substitute (PAA/CMC). The cyanoethyl groups are considered to be at least partly responsible for the value of high
t
Na
+
. Salt dissociation facilitated by nitrile groups was suggested to explain the high cationic transference number of electrolytes in the presence of polyacrylonitrile and succinonitrile.
(44â46)
Further, it was reported that solvated lithium ions are more loosely bound to the cyanoethyl groups than their counteranions.
(36)

The high value of
t
Na
+
supports the high concentration of sodium ions near the antimony particles during sodiation. The concentration polarization observed especially at the end of fast charging is possibly relieved because the lack of charge carriers near the electrodes is resolved in such a high-
t
Na
+
environment. Additionally, the high dielectric constant of pullulan-CN (Îµ = 19 for pullulan-CN vs â¼9.4 for pullulan at 20 Â°C)
(47,48)
possibly encourages the desolvation of sodium ions. The cyanoethyl side chains of the pullulan-CN binder plays an important role in increasing the dielectric constant. This mechanism to reduce the desolvation activation energy possibly improves the charge-transfer kinetics of sodiation, thereby guaranteeing good rate performances.

The superiority of the transference number and the desolvation capability of PAA/pullulan-CN supported the full utilization of the active mass of antimony in composite electrodes. Cyclic voltammograms of antimony anodes in half cells were compared between binders (
Figure S5
). Two cathodic processes for the sodiation of antimony were identified at 0.39 and 0.65 V.
(49,50)
Higher currents were obtained from the PAA/pullulan-CN-based antimony anode instead of its controls. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was estimated from the slope of RandlesâSevcik plots (peak current at 0.39 V vs the root square of scan rate) (
Figure
2
d). The ECSA of PAA/pullulan-CN-based electrode was approximately 1.5 times larger than that of PAA/pullulan, PAA/CMC, or PAA-based electrode. The control binders exhibited a similar value of ECSA.

Considering the balanced mechanical properties between stiffness and elasticity, strong adhesion/cohesion, high transference number, and high dielectric constant, we tested the SIB half cells galvanostatically using the PAA/pullulan-CN binder. The sodiation and desodiation plateaus were found at 0.6 and 0.9 V, respectively, in all cells independent of the binders (
Figure
3
a). The highest initial Coulombic efficiency was obtained from PAA/pullulan-CN when compared to the controls (70% for PAA/pullulan-CN > 69% for PAA/pullulan > 63% for PAA/CMC and PAA). PAA/pullulan-CN was also superior to its controls in terms of cyclability at both 0.2C and 1C (
Figure
3
b,c, respectively). The cells containing pullulan-CN showed good capacity retention at least up to the 200th cycle. However, the cells based on the other four binders did not work in the cycle (
Figures
3
and
S6
). The effects of high transference number and high dielectric constant of the binder were evident. The capacity difference between the pullulan-CN-present and -absent binders became more emphasized as the current (C-rate) increased (
Figure
3
d). The capacity decay of the pullulan-CN-containing cells was not very serious along the C rates (55.9% of the capacity at 0.2C was achieved at 20C). The voltage profiles of charge and discharge rate at 0.2C, 1C, and 20C were shown (
Figure S7
). However, a meaningful capacity was not extracted at 20C from the control binder cells. The rate capability obtained from the PAA/pullulan-CN cells is considered to be the most excellent in comparison to those of previously reported works (
Table S1 and Figure S8
). In addition, the lowest charge transfer resistance (
R
ct
) of the PAA/pullulan-CN cell among cells based on tested binders was confirmed by electrochemical impedance spectra (
Figure S9
):
R
ct
= 3 ohm for PAA/pullulan-CN < 5.1 ohm for PAA/pullulan <5.8 ohm for PAA. Here, the
R
ct
was roughly estimated, including at least two different charge transfer processes. From solution resistances (
R
s
), also, PAA/pullulan-CN was expected to be as good as PAA in terms of electrolyte absorption:
R
s
= 2.24 ohm for PAA/pullulan-CN, 2.25 ohm for PAA/pullulan, 2.52 ohm for PAA.
(51)
In addition, the ability of electrolyte absorption capacity was confirmed by the swelling test. The swellability value of PAA films (â¼41.5%) was much higher than that of other binder films. The PAA/CMC and PAA/pullulan-CN films had the lowest value (â¼1.5%) (
Figure S10
).
(52)

div.p:
Figure 3. Sodiation and desodiation of Sb electrodes with four different binders. 1 = PAA; 2 = PAA/CMC; 3 = PAA/pullulan; 4 = PAA/pullulan-CN. (a) Potential profiles of the first sodiation and desodiation at 0.05C within 0.01â2.0 V vs Na/Na
+
. Initial Coulombic efficiencies were indicated. (b, c) Capacity retention (
Q
) and Coulombic efficiency (Î·) along repeated charge and discharge at 0.2C and 1C. (d) Rate dependency of capacity (1C = 660 mA g
â1
).

div.div:
The morphological change in the antimony electrodes was traced along sodiation and desodiation (
Figure
4
). In the presence of PAA as the binder for antimony electrode (
Figure
4
a), the thickness of the 11.8 Î¼m thick electrode was expanded more than two times after the first sodiation. The original thickness was not fully recovered after the following desodiation. The thickness expansion at 123% (14.5/11.8 Î¼m) was not reversible. The sodiation was followed by desodiation for 100 times; the thickness of the PAA electrode reached 21 Î¼m with the development of macroscopic cracks. As expected from its low elastic modulus and weak cohesion capability, PAA did not maintain electrode integrity and therefore demonstrated poor electrochemical performances. In contrast, the thickness expansion of the bipolymer-cross-linked binders after the first sodiation was not as serious as that of the PAA electrode (
Figure
4
b,c). Their original thicknesses were almost or fully recovered (especially for PAA/pullulan-CN) after the following desodiation. The electrodes based on the pullulan-related binders (thinner than 14 Î¼m) were much thinner than the PAA electrode (thicker than 20 Î¼m) after the 100
th
sodiation/desodiation cycle.

The SEI layers formed on the surface of antimony electrodes were investigated by XPS (
Figure
5
). The C 1s spectra of the antimony anodes experiencing a single cycle of sodiation, followed by desodiation at 0.05C, were composed of multiple peaks responsible for the CâC single bond at 284.8 eV, the ether bond (âCOCâ) at 286.15 eV, the ester bond (âCOORâ) at 288.4 eV, and/or the carboxylate group (âCOOH) peak at 289.5 eV (
Figure
5
a). The CâC bond was expected to originate from carbon black, which was used as a conducting agent in the composite electrodes. The ether and ester bonds could originate from the SEI layer components made from the carbonate electrolyte decomposition.
(53â55)
Additionally, the cross-linkage formed between PAA and pullulan or pullulan-CN possibly intensified the ester peaks. The carboxylate, characterizing the functional group of PAA (PAA in
Figure
5
a), was not found after PAA was cross-linked with pullulan or pullulan-CN (PAA/pullulan and PAA/pullulan-CN in
Figure
5
a). The absence of carboxylate in the C 1s spectra indicates that all carboxylic groups reacted with the hydroxyl groups of pullulan, pullulan-CN, or the surface oxide of antimony to form ester. The amounts of ether and ester in the pullulan-containing binders were much smaller than that in PAA, thereby indicating that the electrolyte decomposition to form the SEI layer was less facilitated in the presence of the pullulan-containing binders.

After ten cycles of sodiation followed by desodiation at 1C, the carbonate peak at 290.3 eV was observed in the XPS spectra of all tested electrodes (
Figure
5
b). It should be noted that the carbonate peaks were not found in the XPS spectra of the first-cycle samples. Therefore, the amount of carbonate formed on the surface, estimated using the relative peak area, was used as a measure of the amount of electrolyte decomposition. The relative area of carbonate peak around 290 eV decreased along 18.7% for PAA > 14.9% for PAA/pullulan > 14.3% for PAA/pullulan-CN. Given that fresh surface generated from crack development and particle pulverization leads to additional electrolyte decomposition, the lowest carbonate content of PAA/pullulan-CN indicates that the binder suppressed the development of crack during repeated sodiation and desodiation as discussed above.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Through this paper, we presented PAA/pullulan-CN as the binder for the antimony anode of SIBs. Two characteristics of the bipolymer-cross-linked binder system improved the reversibility and kinetics of the sodiation/desodiation of antimony. Its balanced mechanical property between stiffness and elasticity suppressed the volume expansion (<130% for PAA/pullulan-CN vs 180% for PAA at the 100
th
cycle of 1C/1C) as well as pulverization, thereby guaranteeing capacity retention along the cycles (
reversibility
gain: capacity at the 200
th
cycle of 1C/1C = 400 mAh g
â1
for PAA/pullulan-CN vs meaningless capacity for PAA). In addition, its high sodium-ion transference number (
t
Na
+
= 0.68 for PAA/pullulan-CN vs 0.49 for PAA/pullulan) provided sodium-ion-rich environments around antimony with a lower desolvation activation required, thereby supporting the improved rate capability (kinetic gain: capacity at 20C = 320 mAh g
â1
for PAA/pullulan-CN vs 122 mAh g
â1
for PAA/pullulan).

The litium half cells and lithium-ion cells were fabricated from germanium nanotubes, Super P carbon black, polyvinylidine difluoride binder, LiCoO2 cathode, microporous polyethylene separator, and an electrolyte consisting of 1.1 M LiPF6 dissolved ethylene carbonate-Et Me carbonate-dimethyl carbonate. Batteries fabricated with germanium nanotube anodes demonstrated high-rate capability with excellent capacity retention and stability over 400 cycles.

A review. Alloy anodes are promising anode materials for lithium-ion batteries due to their high-energy capacity and safety characteristics. However, the com. use of alloy anodes has been hindered to date by their low cycle life and high initial capacity loss. This overview highlights the recent progress in improving and understanding the electrochem. performance of various alloy anodes. The approaches used for performance improvement are summarized, and the causes of first-cycle irreversible capacity loss are discussed. The capacity retentions and irreversible capacity losses of various alloy anodes are compared. Several alloy anodes exhibited excellent cycle life (up to 300 cycles) with high initial coulombic efficiency (80-90%) and large reversible capacity (500-700 mA-h/g).

Pure micrometric antimony can be successfully used as neg. electrode material in Na-ion batteries, sustaining a capacity close to 600 mAh g-1 at a high rate with a Coulombic efficiency of 99 over 160 cycles, an extremely high capacity compared to any other compd. tested against both Li and Na. The reaction mechanism with Na does not simply go through the alloying mechanism obsd. for Li where the intermediate species are those expected from the phase diagram. In the case of Na, the intermediate phases are mostly amorphous and could not be precisely identified. Surprisingly, it is evidenced that a competition takes place at the end of the discharge of the Sb/Na cell between the formation of the hexagonal and the cubic polymorphs of Na3Sb, the last being described in the literature as unstable at atm. pressure and only synthesized under high pressure (1-9 GPa). In addn., fluoroethylene carbonate added to the electrolyte combined with an appropriate electrode formulation based on CM-cellulose, carbon black, and vapor ground carbon fibers seems to be determinant in the excellent performances of this material.

A review. The increase in energy d. and power d. requirements for lithium-ion batteries for com. applications has led to a search for higher capacity electrode materials than those available today. Silicon would seem to be a possible alternative for the graphite or carbon anode because its intercalation capacity is the highest known. However, the large capacity fade obsd. during initial cycling has prevented the silicon anode from being commercialized. Methodologies adopted for reducing the capacity fade obsd. in silicon-based anodes are summarized. The challenges that remain in using silicon and silicon-based anodes are discussed and possible approaches for overcoming them are proposed.

The electrode performance of amorphous phosphorus in aprotic Na cells is examd. Amorphous phosphorus is electrochem. reduced in the Na cells with a three-electron redox process, crystg. into Na3P. Na-P bonds in Na3P have high covalent characteristics. Therefore, the molar volume of Na in Na3P is anomalously small in comparison to other Na-metal alloys that have been used as neg. electrode materials. The theor. volumetric capacity, calcd. at full vol. expansion of amorphous phosphorus electrodes through sodiation, is expected to be 27% larger than that of metallic sodium. However, exptl., it is found that severe electrolyte decompn. results in insufficient reversibility of the electrode materials, owing to the highly reactive Na3P surface. Electrode reversibility is successfully improved by utilizing an electrolyte additive, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). The surface chem. of phosphorus in the aprotic solvent with sodium salts is examd. by hard/soft XPS (PES). PES studies reveal that FEC effectively stabilizes the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI), contg. monovalent phosphorus species and sodium fluoride, and thus electrolyte decompn. is partly suppressed by the relatively stable SEI formed on the surface of phosphorus particles.

We report colloidal synthesis of Sb nanocrystals with mean size tunable in the 10-20 nm range and with narrow size distributions of 7-11%. In comparison to microcryst. Sb, 10 and 20 nm Sb nanocrystals exhibit enhanced rate capability and higher cycling stability as anode materials in rechargeable Li-ion and Na-ion batteries. All three particle sizes of Sb have high and similar Li-ion and Na-ion charge storage capacities of 580-640 mA-h/g at moderate charging/discharging current densities of 0.5-1C (1C rate is 660 mA/g). At all C-rates (0.5-20C, e.g. current densities of 0.33-13.2 A/g), capacities of 20 nm Sb particles are systematically better than for both 10 nm and bulk Sb. At 20C rate, retention of charge storage capacities by 10 and 20 nm Sb nanocrystals can reach 78-85% of the low-rate value, indicating that rate capability of Sb nanostructures can be comparable to the best Li-ion intercalation anodes and is so far unprecedented for Na-ion storage.

Sodium-ion batteries have come up as an alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale applications because of abundant Na storage in the earth crust. Antimony hollow nanospheres obtained by galvanic replacement were first applied as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries and exhibited superior electrochem. performances with high reversible capacity of 622.2 mA-h/g at a c.d. of 50 mA/g after 50 cycles, close to the theor. capacity (660 mA-h/g); even at high c.d. of 1600 mA/g, the reversible capacities can also reach 315 mA-h/g. The benefits of this unique structure can also be extended to lithium-ion batteries, resulting in reversible capacity of 627.3 mA-h/g at a c.d. of 100 mA/g after 50 cycles, and at high c.d. of 1600 mA/g, the reversible capacity is 435.6 mA-h/g. Thus, these benefits from the antimony hollow nanospheres are able to provide a robust architecture for anodes of sodium-ion batteries and lithium-ion batteries.

We have presented a comprehensive study of using chem. dealloying methods to control the morphol. of nanoporous-antimony (NP-Sb) and the size of Sb particles. For the first time, depending on the regulation of the Al-Sb alloy compn., coral-like NP-Sb (NP-Sb70), honeycomb-like NP-Sb (NP-Sb80) and Sb particles (Sb10, Sb30 and Sb45) with different sizes were prepd. through chem. dealloying of Al30Sb70, Al20Sb80, Al90Sb10, Al70Sb30 and Al55Sb45 (at%) alloy ribbon precursors resp., a top-down process. The NP-Sb70 delivered a high capacity of 573.8 mA h g-1 after 200 cycles at a rate of 100 mA g-1 with good rate capability as anode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The excellent electrochem. performance is because of its innovative electrode design, which ensures strong structural integrity, high sodium ion accessibility, and fast electrode transport. This scalable strategy shall pave the way for the mass prodn. of large-capacity electrodes for SIBs and other energy storage systems, providing new guidelines for the optimization of the synthesis of nanostructures.

Cathodic corrosion, a green electrochem. method, has been employed to obtain Sb nanomaterials utilized as anode material for lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. Interestingly, two different corrosion mechanisms are found, coming from the impact of electrolyte, resulting in the formation of hexagonal and amorphous Sb in aq. and org. soln., resp. With the help of water-sol. CM-cellulose binder and the electrolyte additive fluoroethylene carbonate, both hexagonal and amorphous Sb electrodes exhibit good cycling stability when utilized as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. Addnl., both the hexagonal and amorphous Sb electrodes show very good rate capability in lithium-ion batteries. Even at high c.d. (2000 mA g-1), the hexagonal and amorphous Sb give reversible capacities of 422 and 379 mA h g-1, resp. Surprisingly, when used as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries, the hexagonal Sb electrode exhibits a good rate performance of 632, 625, 569, 515, and 426 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 100, 200, 500, 1000, and 2000 mA g-1, resp. However, limited rate performance is obsd. from the amorphous Sb electrode in case of sodium-ion battery due to the large impedance.

Na-ion batteries have recently attracted considerable attention as a promising alternative to Li-ion batteries owing to the natural abundance and low cost of Na compared with Li. Among all proposed anode materials for Na-ion batteries, Sb is a desirable candidate due to its high theor. capacity (660 mA h g-1). Herein, an Sb/multilayer graphene hybrid, in which Sb is homogeneously anchored on multilayer graphene, is produced by a confined vapor deposition method. The chem. bonding can realize robust and intimate contact between Sb and multilayer graphene, and the uniform distribution of Sb and the highly conductive and flexible multilayer graphene can not only improve Na ion diffusion and electronic transport but also stabilize the solid electrolyte interphase upon the large vol. changes of Sb during cycling. Consequently, the Sb/multilayer graphene hybrid shows a high reversible Na storage capacity (452 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1), stable long-term cycling performance with 90% capacity retention after 200 cycles, and excellent rate capability (210 mA h g-1 under 5000 mA g-1). This facile synthesis approach and unique nanostructure can potentially be extended to other alloy materials for Na-ion batteries.

Antimony (Sb) is an attractive anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with a high theor. capacity of 660 mAh g-1. However, its practical application is greatly hindered by the rapid capacity fading which is largely due to the large vol. expansion during sodiation. Tuning the morphol. and structure at the nanoscale or using carbonaceous materials as the buffer layer is essential to address this issue. Here, a facile carbon-coating coupled with a thermal-redn. strategy has been developed to synthesize unique
[emailÂ protected]
coaxial nanotubes. With different annealing time, the hollow space and the amt. of Sb inside the tube can be easily tuned by the partial evapn. of Sb. The as-obtained
[emailÂ protected]
nanotubes exhibit excellent sodium storage properties. The remarkable electrochem. performance results from the unique coaxial nanoarchitecture. Specifically, it delivers a high specific capacity of 407 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 after 240 cycles. Furthermore, a stable capacity of 240 mAh g-1 can be retained at 1.0 A g-1 even after 2000 cycles. Most importantly, high capacities of 350 mAh g-1 and 310 mAh g-1 can be achieved at large current densities of 10 and 20 A g-1, resp., which represents the best rate performance among the reported Sb-based anode materials.

Here we provide the first report on several compns. of ternary Sn-Ge-Sb thin film alloys for application as sodium ion battery (aka NIB, NaB or SIB) anodes, employing Sn50Ge50, Sb50Ge50, and pure Sn, Ge, Sb as baselines. Sn33Ge33Sb33, Sn50Ge25Sb25, Sn60Ge20Sb20, and Sn50Ge50 all demonstrate promising electrochem. behavior, with Sn50Ge25Sb25 being the best overall. This alloy has an initial reversible specific capacity of 833 mAhg-1 (at 85 mAg-1) and 662 mAhg-1 after 50 charge-discharge cycles. Sn50Ge25Sb25 also shows excellent rate capability, displaying a stable capacity of 381 mAhg-1 at a c.d. of 8500 mAg-1 (â¼10C). A survey of published literature indicates that 833 mAhg-1 is among the highest reversible capacities reported for a Sn-based NIB anode, while 381 mAhg-1 represents the optimum fast charge value. HRTEM shows that Sn50Ge25Sb25 is a composite of 10-15 nm Sn and Sn-alloyed Ge nanocrystallites that are densely dispersed within an amorphous matrix. Comparing the microstructures of alloys where the capacity significantly exceeds the rule of mixts. prediction to those where it does not leads us to hypothesize that this new phenomenon originates from the Ge(Sn) that is able to sodiate beyond the 1:1 Na:Ge ratio reported for the pure element. Combined TOF-SIMS, EELS TEM, and FIB anal. demonstrates substantial Na segregation within the film near the current collector interface that is present as early as the second discharge, followed by cycling-induced delamination from the current collector.

The key challenge for high-performance sodium-ion batteries is the exploitation of appropriate electrode materials with a long cycling stability and high rate capability. Here, we report Sb2S5 nanoparticles (â¼5 nm) uniformly encapsulated in three-dimensional (3D) porous graphene foam, which were fabricated by a facile hydrothermal coassembly strategy, as a high-performance anode material for sodium-ion batteries. The as-prepd. composite can be directly used as electrodes without adding a binder or current collector, exhibiting outstanding electrochem. performance with a high reversible capacity (845 mA h g-1 at 0.1 A g-1), ultralong cycling life (91.6% capacity retention after 300 cycles at 0.2 A g-1), and exceptional rate capability (525 mA h g-1 at 10.0 A g-1). This is attributed to fast Na+ ion diffusion from the ultrasmall nanoparticles and excellent elec. transport between the active material and 3D porous graphene, which also provide an effective strategy for anchoring the nanoparticles. Exptl. results show that the Sb2S5 undergoes a reversible reaction of Sb2S5 + 16Na <->tmr 5Na2S + 2Na3Sb during sodiation/desodiation. Moreover, a full cell with Na3(VO0.5)2(PO4)2F2/C cathode and the as-prepd. composite anode was assembled, displaying high output voltage (â¼2.2 V) with a stable capacity of 828 mA h g-1 for anode material (with 100 cycles at 0.1 A g-1), showing the potential for practical application.

Aq.-based natural graphite particulates for fabrication of lithium-ion battery anodes are investigated with emphasis on chem. control of suspension component interactions among graphite particulates, sodium CM-cellulose (CMC), and emulsified styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR). The chem. stability and dispersion properties of the natural graphite particles are characterized using electroacoustic, flow behavior and green microstructural observations, as well as by measurement of pore size. Correlation is made between the dispersion characteristics and the electrochem. performance of the particles. The dispersion stability of the graphite suspension is improved by charge development when both SBR and CMC are incorporated into the graphite suspension, compared with an unstable graphite suspension prepd. with CMC alone. A method to improve the dispersion and homogeneity of the suspension component based on the use of SBR and CMC is proposed. Silicon anode materials have been developed to achieve high capacity lithium ion batteries for operating smart phones and driving elec. vehicles for longer time. Serious vol. expansion induced by lithiation, which is the main drawback of silicon, has been challenged by multi-faceted approaches. Mech. rigid and stiff polymers (e.g. alginate and CM-cellulose) were considered as the good choices of binders for silicon because they grab silicon particles in a tight and rigid way so that pulverization and then break-away of the active mass from elec. pathways are suppressed. Contrary to the public wisdom, in this work, we demonstrate that electrochem. performances are secured better by letting silicon electrodes breathe in and out lithium ions with vol. change rather than by fixing their dimensions. The breathing electrodes were achieved by using a polysaccharide (pullulan), the conformation of which is modulated from chair to boat during elongation. The conformational transition of pullulan was originated from its Î± glycosidic linkages while the conventional rigid polysaccharide binders have Î² linkages.

Si-based Li-ion battery anodes offer specific capacity an order of magnitude beyond that of conventional graphite. However, the formation of stable Si anodes is a challenge because of significant vol. changes occurring during their electrochem. alloying and dealloying with Li. Binder selection and optimization may allow significant improvements in the stability of Si-based anodes. Most studies of Si anodes have involved the use of CM-cellulose and poly(vinylidene fluoride) binders. Herein, we show for the first time that pure poly(acrylic acid), possessing certain mech. properties comparable to those of CM-cellulose but contg. a higher concn. of carboxylic functional groups, may offer superior performance as a binder for Si anodes. We further show the pos. impact of carbon coating on the stability of the anode. The carbon-coated Si nanopowder anodes, tested between 0.01 and 1 V vs. Li/Li+ and contg. as little as 15 wt.% of poly(acrylic acid), showed excellent stability during the first hundred cycles. The results obtained open new avenues to explore a novel series of binders from the polyvinyl acids family.

Binders were reported to play a key role in improving the cycle performance of Si anode materials of lithium-ion batteries. The biopolymer guar gum (GG) is applied as the binder for a silicon nano-particle (SiNP) anode of a lithium-ion battery for the 1st time. Due to the large no. of polar hydroxyl groups in the GG mol., a robust interaction between the GG binder and the SiNPs is achieved, resulting in a stable Si anode during cycling. More specifically, the GG binder can effectively transfer lithium ions to the Si surface, similarly to polyethylene oxide solid electrolytes. When GG is used as a binder, the SiNP anode can deliver an initial discharge capacity â¤3364 mAh/g, with a Coulombic efficiency of 88.3% at the c.d. of 2100 mA/g, and maintain a capacity of 1561 mAh/g after 300 cycles. The electrochem. performance of the SiNP anode with GG binder is significantly improved compared to that of a SiNP anode with a sodium alginate binder, and GG is a promising binder for Si anodes of lithium-ion batteries.

Glycosidic linkages (Î± and Î²) and side chains (-COOH and -OH) were selected and proven as the major factors of the mol. structures. Three different single-component polysaccharides were compared: pectin for Î±-linkages vs. carboxylic Me cellulose (CMC) for Î²-linkages from the linkage's standpoint, and pectin as a COOH-contg. polymer and amylose as its non-COOH counterpart from the side chain's standpoint. Several applications require strong noncovalent adhesion of polymers to substrates. Graft and branched polymers have proven superior to linear polymers, but the mol. mechanism is still unclear. Here, this question was addressed on the single mol. level with an at. force microscopy (AFM) based method. It is detd. how the presence of side chains and their mol. architecture influence the adhesion and the mobility of polymers on solid substrates. Surprisingly, the adhesion of mobile polymers cannot significantly be improved by side chains or their architecture. Only for immobile polymers a significantly higher max. rupture force for graft, bottle-brush, and branched polymers compared to linear chains is measured. Our results suggest that a combination of polymer architecture and strong mol. bonds is necessary to increase the polymer-surface contact area. An increased contact area together with intrachain cohesion (e.g., by entanglements) leads to improved polymer adhesion.

A review. The status of ambient temp. sodium ion batteries is reviewed in light of recent developments in anode, electrolyte and cathode materials. These devices, although early in their stage of development, are promising for large-scale grid storage applications due to the abundance and very low cost of sodium-contg. precursors used to make the components. The engineering knowledge developed recently for highly successful Li ion batteries can be leveraged to ensure rapid progress in this area, although different electrode materials and electrolytes will be required for dual intercalation systems based on sodium. In particular, new anode materials need to be identified, since the graphite anode, commonly used in lithium systems, does not intercalate sodium to any appreciable extent. A wider array of choices is available for cathodes, including high performance layered transition metal oxides and polyanionic compds. Recent developments in electrodes are encouraging, but a great deal of research is necessary, particularly in new electrolytes, and the understanding of the SEI films. The engineering modeling calcns. of Na-ion battery energy d. indicate that 210 Wh kg-1 in gravimetric energy is possible for Na-ion batteries compared to existing Li-ion technol. if a cathode capacity of 200 mAh g-1 and a 500 mAh g-1 anode can be discovered with an av. cell potential of 3.3 V.

A review. We discuss the similarities and dissimilarities of sodium- and lithium-ion batteries in terms of neg. and pos. electrodes. Compared to the comprehensive body of work on lithium-ion batteries, research on sodium-ion batteries is still at the germination stage. Since both sodium and lithium are alkali metals, they share similar chem. properties including ionicity, electronegativity and electrochem. reactivity. They accordingly have comparable synthetic protocols and electrochem. performances, which indicates that sodium-ion batteries can be successfully developed based on previously applied approaches or methods in the lithium counterpart. The electrode materials in Li-ion batteries provide the best library for research on Na-ion batteries because many Na-ion insertion hosts have their roots in Li-ion insertion hosts. However, the larger size and different bonding characteristics of sodium ions influence the thermodn. and/or kinetic properties of sodium-ion batteries, which leads to unexpected behavior in electrochem. performance and reaction mechanism, compared to lithium-ion batteries. This perspective provides a comparative overview of the major developments in the area of pos. and neg. electrode materials in both Li-ion and Na-ion batteries in the past decade. Highlighted are concepts in solid state chem. and electrochem. that have provided new opportunities for tailored design that can be extended to many different electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Graphite, as the most common anode for com. Li-ion batteries, has been reported to have a very low capacity when used as a Na-ion battery anode. It is well known that electrochem. insertion of Na+ into graphite is significantly hindered by the insufficient interlayer spacing. Here we report expanded graphite as a Na-ion battery anode. Prepd. through a process of oxidn. and partial redn. on graphite, expanded graphite has an enlarged interlayer lattice distance of 4.3 Ã yet retains an analogous long-range-ordered layered structure to graphite. In situ transmission electron microscopy has demonstrated that the Na-ion can be reversibly inserted into and extd. from expanded graphite. Galvanostatic studies show that expanded graphite can deliver a high reversible capacity of 284 mAh g-1 at a c.d. of 20 mA g-1, maintain a capacity of 184 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1, and retain 73.92% of its capacity after 2,000 cycles.

Electrolytes are characterized by their ionic conductivity (Ï(i)). It is desirable that overall Ï(i) results from the dominant contribution of the ions of interest (e.g. Li(+) in lithium ion batteries or LIB). However, high values of cationic transference number (t+) achieved by solid or gel electrolytes have resulted in low Ï(i) leading to inferior cell performances. Here we present an organogel polymer electrolyte characterized by a high liquid-electrolyte-level Ï(i) (~10(1) mS cm(-1)) with high t+ of Li(+) (>0.8) for LIB. A conventional liquid electrolyte in presence of a cyano resin was physically and irreversibly gelated at 60Â°C without any initiators and crosslinkers, showing the behavior of lower critical solution temperature. During gelation, Ï(i) of the electrolyte followed a typical Arrhenius-type temperature dependency, even if its viscosity increased dramatically with temperature. Based on the Li(+)-driven ion conduction, LIB using the organogel electrolyte delivered significantly enhanced cyclability and thermal stability.

Polysaccharide elasticity governed by chair-boat transitions of the glucopyranose ring
Marszalek, Piotr E.; Oberhauser, Andres F.; Pang, Yuan-Ping; Fernandez, Julio M.

Many common, biol. important polysaccharides contain pyranose rings made of five carbon atoms and one oxygen atom. They occur in a variety of cellular structures, where they are often subjected to considerable tensile stress. The polysaccharides are thought to respond to this stress by elastic deformation, but the underlying mol. rearrangements allowing such a response remain poorly understood. It is typically assumed, however, that the pyranose ring structure is inelastic and locked into a chair-like conformation. Here we describe single-mol. force measurements on individual polysaccharides that identify the pyranose rings as the structural unit controlling the mol.'s elasticity. In particular, we find that the enthalpic component of the polymer elasticity of amylose, dextran and pullulan is eliminated once their pyranose rings are cleaved. We interpret these observations as indicating that the elasticity of the three polysaccharides results from a force-induced elongation of the ring structure and a final transition from a chair-like to a boat-like conformation. We expect that the force-induced deformation of pyranose rings reported here plays an important role in accommodating mech. stresses and modulating ligand binding in biol. systems.

Na-ion batteries are a potential substitute to Li-ion batteries for energy storage devices. However, their poor electrochem. performance, esp. capacity and rate capability, is the major bottleneck to future development. Here we propose a performance-oriented electrode structure, which is 1D nanostructure arrays with large-scale high ordering, good vertical alignment, and large interval spacing. Benefiting from these structural merits, a great enhancement in electrochem. performance could be achieved. Taking Sb as an example, we firstly report large-scale highly ordered Sb nanorod arrays with uniform large interval spacing (190 nm). In return for this electrode design, high ion accessibility, fast electron transport, and strong electrode integrity are presented here. Used as additive- and binder-free anodes for Na-ion batteries, Sb nanorod arrays showed a high capacity of 620 mA h g-1 at the 100th cycle with a retention of 84% up to 250 cycles at 0.2 A g-1, and a superior rate capability for delivering reversible capacities of 579.7 and 557.7 mA h g-1 at 10 and 20 A g-1, resp. A full cell coupled by a P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 cathode and a Sb nanorod array anode was also constructed, which showed good cycle performance up to 250 cycles, high rate capability up to 20 A g-1, and large energy d. up to 130 Wh kg-1. These excellent electrochem. performances shall pave the way for developing more applications of Sb nanorod arrays in energy storage devices.

The authors demonstrate the important strategy to design suitable electrolyte systems that make the desirable interfacial structure to allow the reversible sodiation/desodiation of Sn4P3 anodes. The study reveals that the remarkable improvement in the electrochem. performance of Sn4P3 anodes for NIBs is achieved by the combination of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) with tris(trimethylsilyl)phosphite (TMSP). The authors clearly present the unique functions of this binary additive combination to build up a protective surface film on the Sn4P3 anode against unwanted electrolyte decompn. and to prevent the formation of the Na15Sn4 phase, which is accompanied by a large vol. expansion during the Na insertion (sodiation) process.

Effect of fluoroethylene carbonate on electrochemical battery performance and the surface chemistry of amorphous MoO2 lithium-ion secondary battery negative electrodes
Park, Jongwoo; Choi, Insoo; Lee, Min Jeong; Kim, Myeong Ho; Lim, Taeho; Park, Kern H.; Jang, Jihyun; Oh, Seung M.; Cho, Sung Ki; Kim, Jae Jeong
Electrochimica Acta

.

Elsevier Ltd.

The effect of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as a co-solvent on electrochem. battery performance and surface chem. was studied at nano-sized amorphous Mo dioxide (a-MoO2) Li-ion secondary battery neg. electrodes. The capacity retention was enhanced as a function of the FEC concn. up to â¼7% after 50 cycles. The surface characterization conducted by EIS, FE-SEM, FTIR, and XPS revealed that the improved battery performance of the a-MoO2 was attributed to the modification of the surface chem. depending on the FEC content. An ion conductive, mech. and electrochem. stable, and thin solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) was developed as a result of successive reductive decompn. of FEC at the a-MoO2 surface. The superior film properties originated from the FEC-reduced products that were rich in polycarbonates and LiF. Based on the findings, SEI formation mechanisms for ethylene carbonate (EC)-derived, FEC-derived, and EC-/FEC-co-derived SEI were also developed. Identification of the mechanisms proposed herein could provide a good understanding of the FEC effect in modifying the surface reaction of typical Li-ion secondary battery neg. electrodes.

Germanium nanotubes, prepd. from core-shell germanium-antimony nanowires using the Kirkendall effect, were evaluated as potential anodes for high-rate [coin-type] lithium secondary batteries against a LiCoO2 cathode. The litium half cells and lithium-ion cells were fabricated from germanium nanotubes, Super P carbon black, polyvinylidine difluoride binder, LiCoO2 cathode, microporous polyethylene separator, and an electrolyte consisting of 1.1 M LiPF6 dissolved ethylene carbonate-Et Me carbonate-dimethyl carbonate. Batteries fabricated with germanium nanotube anodes demonstrated high-rate capability with excellent capacity retention and stability over 400 cycles.

A review. Alloy anodes are promising anode materials for lithium-ion batteries due to their high-energy capacity and safety characteristics. However, the com. use of alloy anodes has been hindered to date by their low cycle life and high initial capacity loss. This overview highlights the recent progress in improving and understanding the electrochem. performance of various alloy anodes. The approaches used for performance improvement are summarized, and the causes of first-cycle irreversible capacity loss are discussed. The capacity retentions and irreversible capacity losses of various alloy anodes are compared. Several alloy anodes exhibited excellent cycle life (up to 300 cycles) with high initial coulombic efficiency (80-90%) and large reversible capacity (500-700 mA-h/g).

Darwiche, Ali; Marino, Cyril; Sougrati, Moulay T.; Fraisse, Bernard; Stievano, Lorenzo; Monconduit, Laure

Pure micrometric antimony can be successfully used as neg. electrode material in Na-ion batteries, sustaining a capacity close to 600 mAh g-1 at a high rate with a Coulombic efficiency of 99 over 160 cycles, an extremely high capacity compared to any other compd. tested against both Li and Na. The reaction mechanism with Na does not simply go through the alloying mechanism obsd. for Li where the intermediate species are those expected from the phase diagram. In the case of Na, the intermediate phases are mostly amorphous and could not be precisely identified. Surprisingly, it is evidenced that a competition takes place at the end of the discharge of the Sb/Na cell between the formation of the hexagonal and the cubic polymorphs of Na3Sb, the last being described in the literature as unstable at atm. pressure and only synthesized under high pressure (1-9 GPa). In addn., fluoroethylene carbonate added to the electrolyte combined with an appropriate electrode formulation based on CM-cellulose, carbon black, and vapor ground carbon fibers seems to be determinant in the excellent performances of this material.

A review. The increase in energy d. and power d. requirements for lithium-ion batteries for com. applications has led to a search for higher capacity electrode materials than those available today. Silicon would seem to be a possible alternative for the graphite or carbon anode because its intercalation capacity is the highest known. However, the large capacity fade obsd. during initial cycling has prevented the silicon anode from being commercialized. Methodologies adopted for reducing the capacity fade obsd. in silicon-based anodes are summarized. The challenges that remain in using silicon and silicon-based anodes are discussed and possible approaches for overcoming them are proposed.

Phosphorus electrodes in sodium cells: small volume expansion by sodiation and the surface-stabilization mechanism in aprotic solvent
Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Matsuura, Yuta; Ishikawa, Toru; Kuze, Satoru; Son, Jin-Young; Cui, Yi-Tao; Oji, Hiroshi; Komaba, Shinichi

The electrode performance of amorphous phosphorus in aprotic Na cells is examd. Amorphous phosphorus is electrochem. reduced in the Na cells with a three-electron redox process, crystg. into Na3P. Na-P bonds in Na3P have high covalent characteristics. Therefore, the molar volume of Na in Na3P is anomalously small in comparison to other Na-metal alloys that have been used as neg. electrode materials. The theor. volumetric capacity, calcd. at full vol. expansion of amorphous phosphorus electrodes through sodiation, is expected to be 27% larger than that of metallic sodium. However, exptl., it is found that severe electrolyte decompn. results in insufficient reversibility of the electrode materials, owing to the highly reactive Na3P surface. Electrode reversibility is successfully improved by utilizing an electrolyte additive, fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). The surface chem. of phosphorus in the aprotic solvent with sodium salts is examd. by hard/soft XPS (PES). PES studies reveal that FEC effectively stabilizes the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI), contg. monovalent phosphorus species and sodium fluoride, and thus electrolyte decompn. is partly suppressed by the relatively stable SEI formed on the surface of phosphorus particles.

We report colloidal synthesis of Sb nanocrystals with mean size tunable in the 10-20 nm range and with narrow size distributions of 7-11%. In comparison to microcryst. Sb, 10 and 20 nm Sb nanocrystals exhibit enhanced rate capability and higher cycling stability as anode materials in rechargeable Li-ion and Na-ion batteries. All three particle sizes of Sb have high and similar Li-ion and Na-ion charge storage capacities of 580-640 mA-h/g at moderate charging/discharging current densities of 0.5-1C (1C rate is 660 mA/g). At all C-rates (0.5-20C, e.g. current densities of 0.33-13.2 A/g), capacities of 20 nm Sb particles are systematically better than for both 10 nm and bulk Sb. At 20C rate, retention of charge storage capacities by 10 and 20 nm Sb nanocrystals can reach 78-85% of the low-rate value, indicating that rate capability of Sb nanostructures can be comparable to the best Li-ion intercalation anodes and is so far unprecedented for Na-ion storage.

Sodium-ion batteries have come up as an alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale applications because of abundant Na storage in the earth crust. Antimony hollow nanospheres obtained by galvanic replacement were first applied as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries and exhibited superior electrochem. performances with high reversible capacity of 622.2 mA-h/g at a c.d. of 50 mA/g after 50 cycles, close to the theor. capacity (660 mA-h/g); even at high c.d. of 1600 mA/g, the reversible capacities can also reach 315 mA-h/g. The benefits of this unique structure can also be extended to lithium-ion batteries, resulting in reversible capacity of 627.3 mA-h/g at a c.d. of 100 mA/g after 50 cycles, and at high c.d. of 1600 mA/g, the reversible capacity is 435.6 mA-h/g. Thus, these benefits from the antimony hollow nanospheres are able to provide a robust architecture for anodes of sodium-ion batteries and lithium-ion batteries.

We have presented a comprehensive study of using chem. dealloying methods to control the morphol. of nanoporous-antimony (NP-Sb) and the size of Sb particles. For the first time, depending on the regulation of the Al-Sb alloy compn., coral-like NP-Sb (NP-Sb70), honeycomb-like NP-Sb (NP-Sb80) and Sb particles (Sb10, Sb30 and Sb45) with different sizes were prepd. through chem. dealloying of Al30Sb70, Al20Sb80, Al90Sb10, Al70Sb30 and Al55Sb45 (at%) alloy ribbon precursors resp., a top-down process. The NP-Sb70 delivered a high capacity of 573.8 mA h g-1 after 200 cycles at a rate of 100 mA g-1 with good rate capability as anode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The excellent electrochem. performance is because of its innovative electrode design, which ensures strong structural integrity, high sodium ion accessibility, and fast electrode transport. This scalable strategy shall pave the way for the mass prodn. of large-capacity electrodes for SIBs and other energy storage systems, providing new guidelines for the optimization of the synthesis of nanostructures.

Cathodic corrosion, a green electrochem. method, has been employed to obtain Sb nanomaterials utilized as anode material for lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. Interestingly, two different corrosion mechanisms are found, coming from the impact of electrolyte, resulting in the formation of hexagonal and amorphous Sb in aq. and org. soln., resp. With the help of water-sol. CM-cellulose binder and the electrolyte additive fluoroethylene carbonate, both hexagonal and amorphous Sb electrodes exhibit good cycling stability when utilized as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. Addnl., both the hexagonal and amorphous Sb electrodes show very good rate capability in lithium-ion batteries. Even at high c.d. (2000 mA g-1), the hexagonal and amorphous Sb give reversible capacities of 422 and 379 mA h g-1, resp. Surprisingly, when used as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries, the hexagonal Sb electrode exhibits a good rate performance of 632, 625, 569, 515, and 426 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 100, 200, 500, 1000, and 2000 mA g-1, resp. However, limited rate performance is obsd. from the amorphous Sb electrode in case of sodium-ion battery due to the large impedance.

Na-ion batteries have recently attracted considerable attention as a promising alternative to Li-ion batteries owing to the natural abundance and low cost of Na compared with Li. Among all proposed anode materials for Na-ion batteries, Sb is a desirable candidate due to its high theor. capacity (660 mA h g-1). Herein, an Sb/multilayer graphene hybrid, in which Sb is homogeneously anchored on multilayer graphene, is produced by a confined vapor deposition method. The chem. bonding can realize robust and intimate contact between Sb and multilayer graphene, and the uniform distribution of Sb and the highly conductive and flexible multilayer graphene can not only improve Na ion diffusion and electronic transport but also stabilize the solid electrolyte interphase upon the large vol. changes of Sb during cycling. Consequently, the Sb/multilayer graphene hybrid shows a high reversible Na storage capacity (452 mA h g-1 at a c.d. of 100 mA g-1), stable long-term cycling performance with 90% capacity retention after 200 cycles, and excellent rate capability (210 mA h g-1 under 5000 mA g-1). This facile synthesis approach and unique nanostructure can potentially be extended to other alloy materials for Na-ion batteries.

Antimony (Sb) is an attractive anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) with a high theor. capacity of 660 mAh g-1. However, its practical application is greatly hindered by the rapid capacity fading which is largely due to the large vol. expansion during sodiation. Tuning the morphol. and structure at the nanoscale or using carbonaceous materials as the buffer layer is essential to address this issue. Here, a facile carbon-coating coupled with a thermal-redn. strategy has been developed to synthesize unique
[emailÂ protected]
coaxial nanotubes. With different annealing time, the hollow space and the amt. of Sb inside the tube can be easily tuned by the partial evapn. of Sb. The as-obtained
[emailÂ protected]
nanotubes exhibit excellent sodium storage properties. The remarkable electrochem. performance results from the unique coaxial nanoarchitecture. Specifically, it delivers a high specific capacity of 407 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 after 240 cycles. Furthermore, a stable capacity of 240 mAh g-1 can be retained at 1.0 A g-1 even after 2000 cycles. Most importantly, high capacities of 350 mAh g-1 and 310 mAh g-1 can be achieved at large current densities of 10 and 20 A g-1, resp., which represents the best rate performance among the reported Sb-based anode materials.

Here we provide the first report on several compns. of ternary Sn-Ge-Sb thin film alloys for application as sodium ion battery (aka NIB, NaB or SIB) anodes, employing Sn50Ge50, Sb50Ge50, and pure Sn, Ge, Sb as baselines. Sn33Ge33Sb33, Sn50Ge25Sb25, Sn60Ge20Sb20, and Sn50Ge50 all demonstrate promising electrochem. behavior, with Sn50Ge25Sb25 being the best overall. This alloy has an initial reversible specific capacity of 833 mAhg-1 (at 85 mAg-1) and 662 mAhg-1 after 50 charge-discharge cycles. Sn50Ge25Sb25 also shows excellent rate capability, displaying a stable capacity of 381 mAhg-1 at a c.d. of 8500 mAg-1 (â¼10C). A survey of published literature indicates that 833 mAhg-1 is among the highest reversible capacities reported for a Sn-based NIB anode, while 381 mAhg-1 represents the optimum fast charge value. HRTEM shows that Sn50Ge25Sb25 is a composite of 10-15 nm Sn and Sn-alloyed Ge nanocrystallites that are densely dispersed within an amorphous matrix. Comparing the microstructures of alloys where the capacity significantly exceeds the rule of mixts. prediction to those where it does not leads us to hypothesize that this new phenomenon originates from the Ge(Sn) that is able to sodiate beyond the 1:1 Na:Ge ratio reported for the pure element. Combined TOF-SIMS, EELS TEM, and FIB anal. demonstrates substantial Na segregation within the film near the current collector interface that is present as early as the second discharge, followed by cycling-induced delamination from the current collector.

The key challenge for high-performance sodium-ion batteries is the exploitation of appropriate electrode materials with a long cycling stability and high rate capability. Here, we report Sb2S5 nanoparticles (â¼5 nm) uniformly encapsulated in three-dimensional (3D) porous graphene foam, which were fabricated by a facile hydrothermal coassembly strategy, as a high-performance anode material for sodium-ion batteries. The as-prepd. composite can be directly used as electrodes without adding a binder or current collector, exhibiting outstanding electrochem. performance with a high reversible capacity (845 mA h g-1 at 0.1 A g-1), ultralong cycling life (91.6% capacity retention after 300 cycles at 0.2 A g-1), and exceptional rate capability (525 mA h g-1 at 10.0 A g-1). This is attributed to fast Na+ ion diffusion from the ultrasmall nanoparticles and excellent elec. transport between the active material and 3D porous graphene, which also provide an effective strategy for anchoring the nanoparticles. Exptl. results show that the Sb2S5 undergoes a reversible reaction of Sb2S5 + 16Na <->tmr 5Na2S + 2Na3Sb during sodiation/desodiation. Moreover, a full cell with Na3(VO0.5)2(PO4)2F2/C cathode and the as-prepd. composite anode was assembled, displaying high output voltage (â¼2.2 V) with a stable capacity of 828 mA h g-1 for anode material (with 100 cycles at 0.1 A g-1), showing the potential for practical application.

Aq.-based natural graphite particulates for fabrication of lithium-ion battery anodes are investigated with emphasis on chem. control of suspension component interactions among graphite particulates, sodium CM-cellulose (CMC), and emulsified styrene-butadiene rubber (SBR). The chem. stability and dispersion properties of the natural graphite particles are characterized using electroacoustic, flow behavior and green microstructural observations, as well as by measurement of pore size. Correlation is made between the dispersion characteristics and the electrochem. performance of the particles. The dispersion stability of the graphite suspension is improved by charge development when both SBR and CMC are incorporated into the graphite suspension, compared with an unstable graphite suspension prepd. with CMC alone. A method to improve the dispersion and homogeneity of the suspension component based on the use of SBR and CMC is proposed. Electrochem. expts. using a Li/org. electrolyte/as-cast natural graphite half-cell and 750-mA-h lithium-ion cells show an initial discharge capacity >340 mA-h/g, improved charge-discharge efficiency, and excellent rate capability.

Silicon anode materials have been developed to achieve high capacity lithium ion batteries for operating smart phones and driving elec. vehicles for longer time. Serious vol. expansion induced by lithiation, which is the main drawback of silicon, has been challenged by multi-faceted approaches. Mech. rigid and stiff polymers (e.g. alginate and CM-cellulose) were considered as the good choices of binders for silicon because they grab silicon particles in a tight and rigid way so that pulverization and then break-away of the active mass from elec. pathways are suppressed. Contrary to the public wisdom, in this work, we demonstrate that electrochem. performances are secured better by letting silicon electrodes breathe in and out lithium ions with vol. change rather than by fixing their dimensions. The breathing electrodes were achieved by using a polysaccharide (pullulan), the conformation of which is modulated from chair to boat during elongation. The conformational transition of pullulan was originated from its Î± glycosidic linkages while the conventional rigid polysaccharide binders have Î² linkages.

Si-based Li-ion battery anodes offer specific capacity an order of magnitude beyond that of conventional graphite. However, the formation of stable Si anodes is a challenge because of significant vol. changes occurring during their electrochem. alloying and dealloying with Li. Binder selection and optimization may allow significant improvements in the stability of Si-based anodes. Most studies of Si anodes have involved the use of CM-cellulose and poly(vinylidene fluoride) binders. Herein, we show for the first time that pure poly(acrylic acid), possessing certain mech. properties comparable to those of CM-cellulose but contg. a higher concn. of carboxylic functional groups, may offer superior performance as a binder for Si anodes. We further show the pos. impact of carbon coating on the stability of the anode. The carbon-coated Si nanopowder anodes, tested between 0.01 and 1 V vs. Li/Li+ and contg. as little as 15 wt.% of poly(acrylic acid), showed excellent stability during the first hundred cycles. The results obtained open new avenues to explore a novel series of binders from the polyvinyl acids family.

Binders were reported to play a key role in improving the cycle performance of Si anode materials of lithium-ion batteries. The biopolymer guar gum (GG) is applied as the binder for a silicon nano-particle (SiNP) anode of a lithium-ion battery for the 1st time. Due to the large no. of polar hydroxyl groups in the GG mol., a robust interaction between the GG binder and the SiNPs is achieved, resulting in a stable Si anode during cycling. More specifically, the GG binder can effectively transfer lithium ions to the Si surface, similarly to polyethylene oxide solid electrolytes. When GG is used as a binder, the SiNP anode can deliver an initial discharge capacity â¤3364 mAh/g, with a Coulombic efficiency of 88.3% at the c.d. of 2100 mA/g, and maintain a capacity of 1561 mAh/g after 300 cycles. The electrochem. performance of the SiNP anode with GG binder is significantly improved compared to that of a SiNP anode with a sodium alginate binder, and GG is a promising binder for Si anodes of lithium-ion batteries.

Several applications require strong noncovalent adhesion of polymers to substrates. Graft and branched polymers have proven superior to linear polymers, but the mol. mechanism is still unclear. Here, this question was addressed on the single mol. level with an at. force microscopy (AFM) based method. It is detd. how the presence of side chains and their mol. architecture influence the adhesion and the mobility of polymers on solid substrates. Surprisingly, the adhesion of mobile polymers cannot significantly be improved by side chains or their architecture. Only for immobile polymers a significantly higher max. rupture force for graft, bottle-brush, and branched polymers compared to linear chains is measured. Our results suggest that a combination of polymer architecture and strong mol. bonds is necessary to increase the polymer-surface contact area. An increased contact area together with intrachain cohesion (e.g., by entanglements) leads to improved polymer adhesion.

A review. The status of ambient temp. sodium ion batteries is reviewed in light of recent developments in anode, electrolyte and cathode materials. These devices, although early in their stage of development, are promising for large-scale grid storage applications due to the abundance and very low cost of sodium-contg. precursors used to make the components. The engineering knowledge developed recently for highly successful Li ion batteries can be leveraged to ensure rapid progress in this area, although different electrode materials and electrolytes will be required for dual intercalation systems based on sodium. In particular, new anode materials need to be identified, since the graphite anode, commonly used in lithium systems, does not intercalate sodium to any appreciable extent. A wider array of choices is available for cathodes, including high performance layered transition metal oxides and polyanionic compds. Recent developments in electrodes are encouraging, but a great deal of research is necessary, particularly in new electrolytes, and the understanding of the SEI films. The engineering modeling calcns. of Na-ion battery energy d. indicate that 210 Wh kg-1 in gravimetric energy is possible for Na-ion batteries compared to existing Li-ion technol. if a cathode capacity of 200 mAh g-1 and a 500 mAh g-1 anode can be discovered with an av. cell potential of 3.3 V.

A review. We discuss the similarities and dissimilarities of sodium- and lithium-ion batteries in terms of neg. and pos. electrodes. Compared to the comprehensive body of work on lithium-ion batteries, research on sodium-ion batteries is still at the germination stage. Since both sodium and lithium are alkali metals, they share similar chem. properties including ionicity, electronegativity and electrochem. reactivity. They accordingly have comparable synthetic protocols and electrochem. performances, which indicates that sodium-ion batteries can be successfully developed based on previously applied approaches or methods in the lithium counterpart. The electrode materials in Li-ion batteries provide the best library for research on Na-ion batteries because many Na-ion insertion hosts have their roots in Li-ion insertion hosts. However, the larger size and different bonding characteristics of sodium ions influence the thermodn. and/or kinetic properties of sodium-ion batteries, which leads to unexpected behavior in electrochem. performance and reaction mechanism, compared to lithium-ion batteries. This perspective provides a comparative overview of the major developments in the area of pos. and neg. electrode materials in both Li-ion and Na-ion batteries in the past decade. Highlighted are concepts in solid state chem. and electrochem. that have provided new opportunities for tailored design that can be extended to many different electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries.
